#Text=THE MAGIC EGG
#Text=The pretty little theatre attached to the building of the Unicorn

#Text=Club had been hired for a certain January afternoon by Mr. Herbert Loring , who wished to give therein a somewhat novel performance , to which he had invited a small audience consisting entirely of friends and acquaintances .
#Text=Loring was a handsome fellow about thirty years old , who had travelled far and studied much .
#Text=He had recently made a long sojourn in the far East , and his friends had been invited to the theatre to see some of the wonderful things he had brought from that country of wonders .

#Text=As Loring was a club-man , and belonged to a family of good social standing , his circle of acquaintances was large , and in this circle a good many unpleasant remarks had been made regarding the proposed entertainment -- made , of course , by the people who had not been invited to be present .

#Text=Some of the gossip on the subject had reached Loring , who did not hesitate to say that he could not talk to a crowd , and that he did not care to show the curious things he had collected to people who would not thoroughly appreciate them .
#Text=He had been very particular in regard to his invitations .
#Text=At three o'clock on the appointed afternoon nearly all the people who had been invited to the Unicorn Theatre were in their seats .
#Text=No one had stayed away except for some very good reason , for it was well known that if Herbert Loring offered to show anything it was worth seeing .
#Text=About forty people were present , who sat talking to one another , or admiring the decoration of the theatre .
#Text=As Loring stood upon the stage -- where he was entirely alone , his exhibition requiring no assistants -- he gazed through a loophole in the curtain upon a very interesting array of faces .

#Text=There were the faces of many men and women of society , of students , of workers in various fields of thought , and even of idlers in all fields of thought ; but there was not one which indicated a frivolous or listless disposition .
#Text=The owners of those faces had come to see something , and they wished to see it .

#Text=For a quarter of an hour after the time announced for the opening of the exhibition Loring peered through the hole in the curtain , and then , although all the people he had expected had not arrived , he felt it would not do for him to wait any longer .
#Text=The audience was composed of well-bred and courteous men and women , but despite their polite self-restraint Loring could see that some of them were getting tired of waiting .
#Text=So , very reluctantly , and feeling that further delay was impossible , he raised the curtain and came forward on the stage .
#Text=Briefly he announced that the exhibition would open with some fireworks he had brought from Corea .

#Text=It was plain to see that the statement that fireworks were about to be set off on a theatre stage , by an amateur , had rather startled some of the audience , and Loring hastened to explain that these were not real fireworks , but that they were contrivances made of colored glass , which were illuminated by the powerful lens of a lantern which was placed out of sight , and while the apparent pyrotechnic display would resemble fireworks of strange and grotesque designs , it would be absolutely without danger .

#Text=He brought out some little bunches of bits of colored glass , hung them at some distance apart on a wire which was stretched across the stage just high enough for him to reach it , and then lighted his lantern , which he placed in one of the wings , lowered all the lights in the theatre , and began his exhibition .

#Text=As Loring turned his lantern on one of the clusters of glass lenses , strips , and points , and , unseen himself , caused them to move by means of long cords attached , the effects were beautiful and marvellous .

#Text=Little wheels of colored fire rapidly revolved , miniature rockets appeared to rise a few feet and to explode in the air , and while all the ordinary forms of fireworks were produced on a diminutive scale , there were some effects that were entirely novel to the audience .

#Text=As the light was turned successively upon one and another of the clusters of glass , sometimes it would flash along the whole line so rapidly that all the various combinations of color and motion seemed to be combined in one , and then for a time each particular set of fireworks would blaze , sparkle , and coruscate by itself , scattering particles of colored light as if they had been real sparks of fire .

#Text=This curious and beautiful exhibition of miniature pyrotechnics was extremely interesting to the audience , who gazed upward with rapt and eager attention at the line of wheels , stars , and revolving spheres .
#Text=So far as interest gave evidence of satisfaction , there was never a better satisfied audience .
#Text=At first there had been some hushed murmurs of pleasure , but very soon the attention of every one seemed so completely engrossed by the dazzling display that they simply gazed in silence .
#Text=For twenty minutes or longer the glittering show went on , and not a sign of weariness or inattention was made by any one of the assembled company .

#Text=Then gradually the colors of the little fireworks faded , the stars and wheels revolved more slowly , the lights in the body of the theatre were gradually raised , and the stage curtain went softly down .
